facts.text: Respondents executed a rent note in respect of agricultural lands, Survey Nos. 32 and 38, situated in village Raipur, in favour of appellant on February 5, 1943, for five years at annual rent of Rs. 785/-. Lease would expire on March 31, 1948.
On April 11, 1946, Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 (Bombay Act XXIX of 1939) applied to East Khandesh area; s.23(1)(b) statutorily extended lease period to ten years, expiring on March 31, 1953.
During subsistence of extended tenancy, Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act LXVII of 1948 came into force, repealing 1939 Act except ss.3, 3A, 4 as modified; ss.5 and 14 material.
Appellant gave notice to respondents on March 11, 1952, intimating lease expiry on March 31, 1953 and calling for delivery of possession thereafter.

Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952 came into operation on January 12, 1953; repealed s.14(2), amended s.5 and added sub-s.(3); tenancy could not be terminated without one year's notice on ground of bona fide personal cultivation etc.
Appellant instituted tenancy proceedings for possession on April 4, 1953, in Court of Mamlatdar Raver, East Khandesh.
Mamlatdar rejected appellant's claim as no statutory notice with prescribed averments given.
Appellant's appeal against Mamlatdar's decision dismissed by appellate authority.
Appellant's revisional application to Bombay Revenue Tribunal succeeded; held amendments not retrospective, appellant entitled to eject.

Respondents challenged Tribunal order via petition under Art. 227 in Bombay High Court; HC allowed petition on April 11, 1957, held amendments retrospective, set aside Tribunal order, restored appellate authority's order.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to eject the respondents without complying with the statutory notice requirements under the amending Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952, i.e., whether the relevant provisions of the amending Act are retrospective in operation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Technical requirements of valid notice under amending Act XXXIII of 1952 do not apply as provisions are not retrospective; notice given on March 11, 1952 suffices.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Argued relying on Sakharam alias Bapusaheb Narayan Sanas v. Manikchand Motichand Shah

respondent_arguments.text: Amendments of Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952 are retrospective; appellant failed to give statutory notice with prescribed averments for termination.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952, s.5 as amended

court_reasoning.text: Amending Act XXXIII of 1952 extended tenancy automatically via proviso to s.5(1); expiration did not occur on March 31, 1953; appellant must comply with new notice for safeguarded tenancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Just as s.23(1)(b) of 1939 Act extended lease from 5 to 10 years without complaint, further extensions by 1952 Act cannot be complained against.

court_reasoning.text: Right to eject accrues only on tenancy termination, not on notice; before right accrued on March 31, 1953, 1952 Act intervened requiring valid notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between existing right and vested right; Act affects future operation on existing leases, not retrospective in prohibitory sense.

court_reasoning.text: Approved Jivabhai Purshottam v. Chhagan Karson and Durlabbhai Fakirbhai v. Jhaberbhai Bhikabhai; crucial date is when right to terminate matures (tenancy end), not notice date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1952 Act imposes new limitation on landlord's right to possession.

court_reasoning.text: Sakharam case on s.88 of 1948 Act not analogous.

holdings.text: Provisions of amending Act XXXIII of 1952 apply to proceedings; appellant not entitled to eject without valid notice as prescribed; amendments not retrospective but operate on future rights under existing leases.

precedents_cited.relevance: Buckley L.J. observation: retrospective operation vs. interference with existing rights; Act affecting future rights under past leases not retrospective.
Approved Bombay HC full bench on s.34(2A) of 1952 Act; crucial date for restrictions is tenancy termination date.
Full Bench Bombay HC: 1952 Act applies where notice period expired after Act; new limitation on ejectment right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sakharam alias Bapusaheb Narayan Sanas v. Manikchand Motichand Shah
precedents_cited.relevance: s.88 of 1948 Act prospective; not analogous to 1952 amending Act provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 (Bombay Act XXIX of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutorily extended lease from 5 to 10 years.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 (LXVII of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Original provisions on tenancy duration and termination; s.5 deemed minimum 10 years, terminable per s.14(2).

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952
sections: Amendments to s.5(1) proviso, s.5(2), adds s.5(3); repeals s.14(2)
statutes_cited.relevance: Automatic renewal every 10 years; termination requires 1 year notice for bona fide personal cultivation; applies to case.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Respondents' petition to Bombay High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Bombay High Court order that appellant not entitled to eject respondents without complying with notice requirements under Bombay Act XXXIII of 1952; Revenue Tribunal order set aside, appellate authority's dismissal restored.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; respondents retain possession.

key_quotes.text: "Every lease subsisting on the said date... shall be deemed to be for a period of not less than ten years."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.23(1)(b) of 1939 Act extending lease.

key_quotes.text: "retrospective operation is one matter and interference with existing rights is another."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Buckley L.J. in West v. Gwynne distinguishing retrospective effect.

key_quotes.text: "the crucial date is not the date of notice but the date on which the right to terminate matures that is the date on which the tenancy stands terminated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Durlabbhai case, approved by SC; key to applying amendments.
